titleStmt.title: M54, 5 of 11. [Anon: a more crowded, a more divided audience...]. Typescript fragment, 3 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 5 of 11. [a more crowded, a more divided audience...]. Typescript fragment, 3 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: a more crowded, a more divided audience, to a

public which desires
accordind according to its education, its poverty,

it its wealth,
n w now history, now instruction, now poetry itself,
and now whatever will make them forget the drab, the
mudcoloured, the dismal in their own lives. As the book
becomes more and more spun over with these influences,
the thing that the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered. It is only to be discovered in a flash of
recognition Thus some say they that their beards
bristle when they come up on it; others that a thrill
runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengage the song

from its encumbrances becomes as time
gos goes on a task for
the critic-- that specially equipped taster and trier
who was not yet in existence in print when Spenser [illeg.] emerged

weed
hunf hung
peral pearl
enc sted encrusted from the depths of silence.

quote.l: "For why, a Gods' name, may not we, as else the

Greekes, have the kingdome of our owne
langauge language , and measure
our accents by the sound, reserving the quantity to the verse
Why in Gods name may not we have the kingdom of our own

p.l:
lanague language --- thus he proves himself word
cosncious , an

artist, aware of his
meidum medium , aware that words are not

paint, nor music;
nbut but have their possibilities, their
mlimitations limitations . To be thus aware, the writer must

have a past behind him; as the
hisrian historian to see the present,
must set it against an earlier age. To Spenser, the golden
age was Cahu Chaucers. Dan Chaucer, well of English

l.quote: Of thine owne spirit which doth in me survive

p.l:
He looks back to
Cah cer Chaucer ; he descends from
Cahucer Chaucer .

It was Chaucer that gave him the
meausre measure
stabdard standard by which to

measure
hiw his own words. But Where the modern writer
attackes attacks the

actual works of some
on one of the generation that is just
gone, making that book the kicking off point starting point in another

direction, Spensers revolt was against no
particualr particular writer
---had not years of silence intervened? who was there in English save Chaucer?--- but against the
langauge language itself, its decay, since Chaucer, its corruption.
It was partly as an antidote to his own facility; that he

needed him. He found the e
ourge urge which the self critical
writer so often applies to his own disease in the old English
words that were now obsolete. A glossary was added to the
Shepherds Calendar to explain them. But partly he used the
crabbed, English of the past not as we in our day
seek to bring back the sharpness which much use has worn
smooth; but to restrain what was to come. He was, as we are not

cannot be, aware of the future. Everywhere, in
ballds ballads ,
songs, talk in the street, at the tavern, at the back

door, he heard
wit with his acute ear for sound

thxx something rising, moving,
buursting bursting up

from
beanth beneath [illeg.] the old exact words; the crabbed but precise

language of Chaucer. Was it not [illeg.] to restrain that
insur ction insurrection
thzthe that he looked back to the Canterbury Pilgrims?
Yet what comparison is possible between the poetry of
Chaucer and the poetry of Spenser? The one clear, sharp,

me erry merry ; definite;
strifding striding straight on. the other sen
sisensuous sensuous , sinuous, dallying, winding in out of the glooms

of
th the forest glades. The one direct,
abo t about this real

man, this real woman, here and now;
th the other making qua

qualities
og of
noblenees nobleness of baseness in to
symblic symbolic Knights,

or
dawrfs dwarfs ; and sending this
visionay visionary company,
thse these

ladies and demons, these Squires and
domerdaries dromedaries ,

through time which is neither past
npr nor present,

through lands which are neither hxxxx known or
unkwon unknown . Like

the figures in dreams they are distorted;
y tlike like dreams

very vivid, now close, now
dfading fading away. Now,

like the
fgures figures in some great fresco, they cxmxmxmxmx

are composed grouped, with the flowers
grwoing growing at their feet, and
behind them marble pillars, or trees with bright birds
and with the libbard and the lion couchant or romaning.
The monotony of the metre, flinging its
curve of sound [like a wave that always falls] there fills and
falls, like a wave, is beneath them. There is no tension;
no direction. but always movement, on and on and bright

visons visions , [and folded in this
inactation incantation we
drwise drowse and
sleep; but again, wake so such is the and we sleep,
so that we drowse yet yet a start awake.
English poetry, then, might have continued to be a v

book read aloud; a pageant; a recollection;
somet ing something half

seen half heard, by the leisured, listening in
th the great
room to some one reading aloud. Onxmxmxmxmxmxm
But there was the other voice. - the voice of Anon;
xmxmxmxmxmx not as we hear it, reading those first

carbbed crabbed lyrics in the beginning
ot of the anthology; but the
voice that Spenser heard; loud; rough; brutal.
